title: Feature detection for supported clipboard formats

labels.name: ready to add
labels.description: Appears ready to add to the table of positions.

body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Feature detection for supported clipboard formats
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/clipboard-apis/#clipboard-item-interface, https://w3c.github.io/clipboard-apis/#dom-clipboarditem-supports
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/issues/170
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @snianu @sanketj
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug---- @edgarchen

### Other information
Note that this was discussed in the EditingWG meeting and was approved by representatives from Webkit, FF & Chromium: https://www.w3.org/2022/04/14-editing-minutes.html#r01

Positive signal from Gecko: https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/issues/170#issuecomment-1064240391
Web developers: Strongly positive (https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/issues/165#issuecomment-1197976360) Multiple Github issues were filed for this feature: https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/issues/165#issuecomment-1197976360 https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/issues/67#issuecomment-650439507 https://github.com/w3c/clipboard-apis/issues/170

### Summary
Currently during async clipboard write operation, there is no way for the web authors to detect if a particular mime type is supported by the UAs or not before attempting to actually write the formats to the clipboard. This not only affects developer ergonomics as now web authors have to attempt to write to the clipboard first in order to find out whether write failed due to a particular mime type not supported by the UAs (or sometimes add version checks that are unreliable at best), but also leads to unnecessary cost in terms of CPU cycles, COGS etc in order to produce an expensive web custom format which may not be supported by a particular browser.

title: TextTrackCue enhancements for programmatic subtitle and caption presentation
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: TextTrackCue enhancements for programmatic subtitle and caption presentation
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): http://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9771
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WebKit/explainers/tree/main/texttracks
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @marcoscaceres @hober @eric-carlson 
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1855236
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @zcorpan @Emilio (was unsure who to ping here... maybe one of you can ping the right folks? 🙏)

### Other information

Native UA rendering of out-of-band subtitles and captions is currently only possible with WebVTT. If a site can't or won't make its subtitles available in-band, and can't or won't publish its subtitles and captions in WebVTT, the site must render its subtitles and captions itself.

This proposal aims to:

- Allow video publishers to continue storing captions in legacy or custom formats.
- Make sure users can control the presence and style of captions with system accessibility settings.
- Allow captions to be served in custom formats, but still be rendered by the browser engine.

We (WebKit) would like to make the following changes to HTML:

- Exposes a constructor for TextTrackCue which takes startTime, endTime, and cueNode arguments.
- Defines authoring and processing requirements for cue fragments
- Adds cue and cuebackground global attributes.
- Add infrastructure for selecting ::cue and ::cue-background pseudo elements, which can then be styles by the CSS or the system.

title: MediaStreamTrack Statistics (Video)
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Media Capture and Streams Extensions, section "MediaStreamTrack Statistics"
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-extensions/#mediastreamtrack-statistics
* Proposal author(s): @henbos
* Mozillians who can provide input: @jan-ivar 

Video conferencing web developers (Google Meet) have asked for an API to know the actual camera frame rate as well as an ability to get a signal from the stack if frames are being dropped somewhere in the pipeline.

The problem with `MediaStreamTrack.getSettings().frameRate` is that it only provides you with the camera's configured frame rate, say 30. In reality, it is common for the actual frame rate to vary such as due to low lighting conditions. In rare circumstances, frames could even get dropped by the user agent, such as if the system is under heavy load or buffers are not being released on time for some reason.

The track stats API provides valuable insights. Here are real world scenarios that have been observed, but have been hard to investigate without this API:
- A USB hub between the camera and the PC reduced the camera fps (`track.stats.totalFrames`/s) in half.
- In screensharing of static content, an app may only want to encode frames when the screen has changed (e.g. change presentation slide). An app that does this may find that a frame is discarded due to the frame decimation algorithm (`++track.stats.discardedFrames`) and needs to send to produce another frame (else the next presentation slide is never encoded and sent to the other participants).
- If the system is under heavy load or there are other issues with the stack, frames could be dropped for other reasons (`track.stats.totalFrames - track.stats.deliveredFrames - track.stats.discardedFrames > 0`). This is rare but it deserves to be flagged when it happens.

Having an API can help notify the user, troubleshoot (e.g. USB hub...) or provide A/B diagnostics when a web app is launching new features. The motivation is similar to the `RTCPeerConnection.getStats()` API, but there are `MediaStreamTrack` use cases that don't depend on WebRTC so it makes more sense to have the API on the track.

The metrics are expressed as total counters as opposed to frame rates because this allows the app to calculate average frame rates over any interval (by polling twice and looking at delta frames / delta seconds) or to provide total number of frames dropped or discarded for the entire capture session. Some apps want rates for every second, others every 10 seconds, and other may just care about the session total. In the case of discarded/dropped frames there are use cases where total counters are preferred, or else the app has to poll excessively in order not to "miss" any time a drop happened.

### Other information

At the time of writing, the `track.stats` API is only defined for video tracks. I plan to submit a PR that also adds audio stats which will have different metrics definition and a different interface, but the API shape will follow the same pattern, i.e. the app should be able to call `track.stats` on an audio track in the future as well.

title: Extending Storage Access API (SAA) to non-cookie storage
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Extending Storage Access API (SAA) to non-cookie storage
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://privacycg.github.io/saa-non-cookie-storage/
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @arichiv @johannhof 
* Bugtracker URL: https://crbug.com/1484966
* Safari Position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/262
* TAG:  https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/906

### Other information

We propose an extension of the Storage Access API (backwards compatible) to allow access to unpartitioned (cookie and non-cookie) storage in a third-party context, and imagine the API mechanics to be roughly like this (JS running in an embedded iframe):

// Request a new storage handle via rSA (this should prompt the user)
let handle = await document.requestStorageAccess({all: true});
// Write some cross-site localstorage
handle.localStorage.setItem("userid", "1234");
// Open or create an indexedDB that is shared with the 1P context
let messageDB = handle.defaultBucket.indexedDB.open("messages");

The same flow would be used by iframes to get a storage handle when their top-level ancestor successfully called rSAFor, just that in this case the storage-access permission was already granted and thus the rSA call would not require a user gesture or show a prompt, allowing for “hidden” iframes accessing storage.

title: Fire toggle events using microtasks
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Fire toggle events using microtasks
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9775
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/9046
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts):
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug---- 

### Other information

The toggle events for the popover attribute and the details element, as well as the close event for dialog elements, currently post a task to the DOM manipulation task source to fire these events asynchronously. This means that the event could fire before or after the next render, which could lead to flaky rendering for one frame. By using microtasks instead, the event will always fire before the next render. This was suggested in this HTML spec issue: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/9046

### Other information

Users often depend on websites trusting the client environment they run in. This trust may assume that the client environment is honest about certain aspects of itself, keeps user data and intellectual property secure, and is transparent about whether or not a human is using it. This trust is the backbone of the open internet, critical for the safety of user data and for the sustainability of the website’s business.

title: Device Bound Session Credentials
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Device Bound Session Credentials
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): 
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/dbsc/blob/main/README.md
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @kristianmonsen
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): 

### Other information

In their words "Device Bound Session Credentials (DBSC) aims to reduce account hijacking caused by cookie theft. It does so by introducing a protocol and browser infrastructure to maintain and prove possession of a cryptographic key. The main challenge with cookies as an authentication mechanism is that they only lend themselves to bearer-token schemes. On desktop operating systems, application isolation is lacking and local malware can generally access anything that the browser itself can, and the browser must be able to access cookies. On the other hand, authentication with a private key allows for the use of system-level protection against key exfiltration."

title: Add a close event to MessagePort
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Add a close event to MessagePort
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): 
* Explainer URL (if available):https://github.com/fergald/explainer-messageport-close
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @fergald @nononokam
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @asutherland 

### Other information
Currently, there is no timely and reliable way to detect when a MessagePort becomes disentangled, which makes it difficult to release resources associated with ports. [This issue](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/1766) has a long discussion of the problem and potential solutions.  Some users have used the unload event to detect disconnect, but [it is deprecated](https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/bfcache-dev/c/Mymq3N7J3z4). Therefore, [The approach available now](https://github.com/fergald/docs/blob/master/explainers/permissions-policy-deprecate-unload.md#messagechannel) is to hold a MessagePort in [WeakRef](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/WeakRef) and periodically check if this port has been garbage collected by using deref() or to make use of a page-hide event, which is quite inefficient.
So, I propose adding a close event. For example, if there are two entangled ports, portA and portB, and portA is closed, the close event is fired on portB.

title: Coding Independent Code Points (CICP) and PNG `cICP`
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->
<!-- Asking for a standards position on PNG seems odd, though -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: PNG, section 11.3.2.6 cICP Coding-independent code points 
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/PNG-spec/#cICP-chunk
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/w3c/PNG-spec/blob/main/Third_Edition_Explainer.md#labelling-hdr-content
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): PNG WG
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1862245
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): 

### Other information

CICP is a way to identify the color space and transfer function; specified in ITU-T-H.273 originally for video formats, it is now widely deployed and starting to be used in image formats such as AVIF and JPEG-XL. It is particularly used for HDR content, but can also be used for SDR content. Compared to an embedded ICC profile, which can be 10-20k for an RGB colorspace, it only adds 4 bytes of data because it is an enumeration.

For example, an image in BT.2100 color space with the PQ transfer function would signal this with the following four bytes:

> 9 16 0 1

while an image in Display P3 would use

> 12 13 0 1

Gecko already supports CICP in AVIF, see https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1634741

The need for PNG to support HDR images was identified at the [W3C Color Workshop](https://www.w3.org/Graphics/Color/Workshop/report.html) and incubated in the [Color on the Web CG](https://github.com/w3c/ColorWeb-CG/blob/main/hdr-in-png-requirements.md)

PNG Third Edition a[dds the `cICP` chunk](https://w3c.github.io/PNG-spec/#cICP-chunk) for CICP, and this is already [supported in Chrome](https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3705739). It is produced by image editing applications including darktable and Adobe Photoshop.

title: Opener Protections
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Opener Storage Partitioning
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://arichiv.github.io/opener-storage-partitioning/
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @arichiv @johannhof
* Bug Tracker URL (optional): https://crbug.com/1159586
* WebKit Position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/277
* Tag Position: https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/916

### Other information

Our goal is to maintain cross-page communication where important to web function while striking a better balance with user-privacy.

This will be done in two steps. First, whenever a frame navigates cross-origin any other windows with a window.opener handle pointing to the navigating frame will have that handle cleared. Second, either (a) any frames with a valid window.opener (or window.top.opener) handle at the time of navigation will have transient storage via a StorageKey nonce instead of access to standard first- and third-party StorageKeys or (b) the opener will be severed by default until user interaction or an API call restores it.

The first proposal should be less disruptive than either of the second, but metrics will need to be gathered on both. Once implemented, these proposals together prevent any synchronous or asynchronous communication between a first- and third-party storage bucket for the same origin. Instead, communication between two buckets for the same origin will only be possible if one of the buckets is transient. This mitigates the threats we are concerned with.

### Other information

Navigation Activation exposes information about the most recent cross-document navigation (aka "activation").
It exposes the old URL, new URL, and navigation type.
This is mainly useful for cross-document view transitions.

Navigation Activation is namespaced to the navigation API and uses the `NavigationHistoryEntry` interface, but other than that it's a somewhat self-contained.

title: MediaStreamTrack Statistics (Audio)
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Media Capture and Streams Extensions, section MediaStreamTrack Statistics and specifically the MediaStreamTrackAudioStats subsection.
* Specification or proposal URL: https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-extensions/#dom-mediastreamtrackaudiostats
* Proposal author(s): @henbos
* Mozillians who can provide input: @padenot @jan-ivar 

This request related to the `track.stats` API for when `MediaStreamTrack` is an audio track sourced from `getUserMedia`. The API shape is the same as for video (previous standards-position: https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/895) but audio tracks has a separate interface defined for the metrics since these definitions are specific to audio: [MediaStreamTrackAudioStats](https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-extensions/#dom-mediastreamtrackaudiostats).

The motivation for this API is to monitor quality, on an individual basis, e.g. a user of a web app is experiencing quality issues, which part of the pipeline is responsible or is it caused by the device needs to be debugged using metrics from the wild specific to that app and user, and for A/B testing, for example understanding how rolling out features in video conferencing web app affect the quality of the users of that web app. The latency metric may additionally be used by a web app as input for example to WebAudio which may aid audio processing use cases, but this is also useful as a quality indicator too.

So there are two types of metrics exposed by this API:
1. Audio frame counters and duration, including frames delivered and total frames. This allows calculating dropped frames (or frames duration) as "dropped = total - delivered". This allows estimating glitches, such device connectivity issues (e.g. poor bluetooth connection), the OS or user agent is dropping frames or other device issues. It is important to have this in JS because issues like this typically happen in the wild rather than in lab conditions.
2. Microphone input latency. This is always useful and I believe @padenot has said that web developers have been asking for this for years? At the time of writing `latency` has been merged into the spec but the PR that adds min/max/avg latency is still in review: https://github.com/w3c/mediacapture-extensions/pull/134 (**Update:** the resolution from last meeting is to [adopt the PR](https://www.w3.org/2023/12/05-webrtc-minutes.html#t05)).

Mozilla has expressed interest in latency but has opposed measuring audio drops, see below for history and more information.

### Other information
- The dropped frames disagreement was discussed in the September WebRTC WG meeting ([link with timestamp](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xJMXnf3Qwh8&t=641s)) where no consensus was reached.
- https://github.com/w3c/mediacapture-extensions/issues/129 is the issue for the disagreement, which adds some information to the discussion, including how device connectivity can cause glitches before audio reaches the UA. This issue is still open.
- The blink-dev [Intent to Prototype](https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/vUbD_psbPL8) shows support from GoTo, Teams and Zoom.

WebAuthn: Allow for credential creation in a cross-origin iframe
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: WebAuthn
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/#publickey-credentials-create-feature
* Explainer URL (if available):
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @stephenmcgruer
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): 

### Other information

Hello Mozilla friends :)

I'm requested a formal standards position on the ability to create a credential in a cross-origin iframe in WebAuthn. This was added to the spec in https://github.com/w3c/webauthn/pull/1801, after having been discussed in https://github.com/w3c/webauthn/issues/1656 as well as in WebAuthn Working Group meetings.

This feature allows web developers to create WebAuthn credentials (that is, "publickey" credentials, aka passkeys) in cross-origin iframes. This will allow developers to create passkeys in embedded scenarios, such as after an identity step-up flow where the Relying Party is providing a federated identity experience. Two conditions are required for this new ability, for security reasons:

1. The iframe has a publickey-credentials-create-feature permission policy.
2. The iframe has transient user activation.

title: Viewport Capture
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Viewport Capture
* Specification URL: https://www.w3.org/TR/mediacapture-viewport/
* Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzil.la/1813091
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @jan-ivar, @martinthomson

### Other information

This API ([getViewportMedia](https://www.w3.org/TR/mediacapture-viewport/#dom-mediadevices-getviewportmedia)) lets site-isolated webpages screen-capture themselves, eliminating the need for a content picker. Target use cases are client-side "record meeting" features, as well as integrating video conferencing into slideware applications.

It contains privacy features absent in [getDisplayMedia()](https://www.w3.org/TR/screen-capture/#dom-mediadevices-getdisplaymedia) and https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/857, to address [privacy concerns inherent in self-capture](https://blog.mozilla.org/webrtc/share-browser-windows-entire-screen-sites-trust/):
1. The API is limited to [cross-origin isolated](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/webappapis.html#concept-settings-object-cross-origin-isolated-capability) webpages.
2. The API is opt-in through `Document-Policy: viewport-capture` and `Require-Document-Policy: viewport-capture`

title: `line-clamp` CSS property (collapse variant)
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: `line-clamp` CSS property (collapse variant)
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): w3c/csswg-drafts#7708
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/Igalia/explainers/blob/main/css/line-clamp/README.md
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @emilio, @bfgeek, @frivoal
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @emilio 

### Other information

CSS Overflow Level 4 defines `line-clamp` based on fragmentation (https://drafts.csswg.org/css-overflow-4/#line-clamp), but that is not feasible for Gecko to implement anytime soon. Due to that, @emilio opened w3c/csswg-drafts#7708 to discuss a variant of `line-clamp` that is based on hiding lines and boxes from paint instead ("the collapse variant"). There is no spec text written for this variant yet, but the CSSWG decided to greenlight both variants for prototyping, and in Chromium we are currently planning to prototype it, rather than the fragmentation-based variant.

title: [css-color-adjust-1] Root non-overlay scrollbars used color scheme
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: CSS Color Adjustment Module Level 1
* Specification or proposal URL: https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-adjust-1/
* CSSWG issue: https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/8603
* Proposal authors: [@ogerchikov](https://github.com/ogerchikov) [@yshalivskyy](https://github.com/yshalivskyy)

### Problem statement
Many web pages don't specify the support for light/dark color schemes using CSS "color-scheme" property or meta tags. In such a case, the used color scheme is light for scrollbars and other interactive UI elements despite the user preference set on the browser/OS level. Although the behavior is expected for elements which are part of the web content, viewport non-overlay scrollbars always stay on the side of the page and are treated by users as a part of the browser UI. The current behavior confuses users who have selected dark mode and expect viewport scrollbars to follow their choice.

### Proposed solution
The proposed solution is to make the browser use the user's preferred color scheme to render the viewport scrollbars if the value of "page’s supported color schemes" is 'normal' or not specified, and the computed value of the color-scheme for the root element is 'normal'. Viewport scrollbars can be considered to be outside the web content. Therefore, the user agents should honor the user's preferred color scheme when rendering viewport scrollbars if page authors have not explicitly specified support for color schemes.

### Bugs tracking this feature
Chromestatus: [Used color scheme root scrollbars - Chrome Platform Status (chromestatus.com)](https://chromestatus.com/feature/5089486318075904?gate=5131964212576256) 
Chromium: [Make root viewport non-overlay scrollbars follow the user's preferred color scheme by default [40259909] - Chromium](https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40259909)

#### Related bugs
Mozilla Bugzilla: [On some websites, the scrollbars that appear from pinch zooming are different theme than non-zoomed scrollbar](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1859940)

title: CSS Nesting: @nest
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: CSS Nesting
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://drafts.csswg.org/css-nesting/
* Explainer URL (if available):
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @tabatkins
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): https://caniuse.com/css-nesting
* Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1648037
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @emilio
* WebKit position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/337

### Other information

Basically [this proposal](https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/8738#issuecomment-2057868087) from Tab.

I am a bit reluctant to ship this since we have a major open issue about how it should appear in CSSOM (https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10234), but apparently the CSSWG wants to ship `@nest` as currently specified _now_, then consider any additional changes later (https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10234#issuecomment-2067746133, https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10234#issuecomment-2069212736).

So I am specifically asking for a position on shipping the (possibly intermediate) state of `@nest` as it's currently specified, despite https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/10234 not being resolved.

title: Still on SerialPort API
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Reconsidering the SerialPort API position
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/SerialPort
* Explainer URL (if available): interacting with the plethora of IoT and educational devices out there https://pyscript.com/@agiammarchi/micro-repl/latest
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): 
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/336
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): 

### Other information

I am working on a project that needs to show kids to grown up users: *works in Chrome/ium* and as long standing Web supporter this is one of those cases it's not me being sloppy on cross-browser testing, it's rather other vendors making it impossible for the project I am working on to work on "*the Web Platform*".

I have read almost the entirety of this thread https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/336 and had no chance to chime in but, for what I've understood, the security concern is not different from a basic `<input type="file">` any malicious Web page could present, any malicious Web page could influence the user about what to upload, so that any malicious Web page could also read both sensible data or configuration files from any user surfing that malicious Web page.

While asking users to download an `.exe` file or anything like that instead which, once granted Admin privileges would harm them even more, seems like "*the solution*" to that thread, I am dealing with thousand of kids willing to just use their browsers to interact with "*this or that SBC*" so that when kids, or even adults, are using projects that are basing their default OS to Firefox, are incapable of learning, having fun, or create amazing projects out of the Web, which used to be a technology to enable everyone, not a technology to patronize and overload their ideas, or possibilities, instead.

Accordingly, as much as I'd love to remove the "*need for Chrome/ium*" mandatory alert on whatever I am building, these are days nobody can even blame the Web developer behind anymore, as constraints are all over the major vendors responsibility.

This is true for all *MicroPython* boards as well as *Espruino* or others, the need for a particular Web extension to do something otherwise impossible out of extensions (which are just yet another extra user explict intent) makes literally no sense, when an extension just lands over an extra explicit user consent.

I am hoping that anyone reading this *might* have a second thought, but I am unfortunately sure this will get blocked and closed at speed light instead, keeping the idea that Firefox is not what people think it is anymore, just another gatekeeping in the Web industry / reality 😥

title: Partitioned Popins
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Partitioned Popins
* GitHub URL: https://github.com/arichiv/partitioned-popins/
* Explainer URL: https://github.com/arichiv/partitioned-popins/blob/main/README.md
* Spec URL: TBD
* Proposal authors: @arichiv @johannhof @krgovind
* Bug Tracker URL: https://issues.chromium.org/issues/340606651
* Chrome Feature URL: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5949561398099968
* Mozillians who can provide input: @bvandersloot-mozilla 
* WebKit standards-position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/349
* Tag Review: https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/956

### Other information

A new web primitive is needed to cover short-lived popup use cases which require access to storage partitioned by the popup opener. This primitive should be private and secure by default, while providing a consistent UI experience across user agents. To solve this need, we propose the “Partitioned Popin”, a type of pop-up for loading web content with two unique new features: a modal-like UI relative to its opener tab and cookies/storage being partitioned to its opener context.

title: Timing Info for ServiceWorker static routing API
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification Title: Timing Info for ServiceWorker static routing API
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): 
* Explainer URL (if available):  [explainer](https://github.com/WICG/service-worker-static-routing-api/blob/main/resource-timing-api.md)
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts):  @quasi-mod, @yoshisatoyanagisawa
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional):
* WebKit standards-position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/354

### Other information

Service Worker provides timing information to mark certain points in time. This is exposed and used by the navigation timing API as well as the resource timing API. It currently records two times:

- Start time
- Fetch event dispatch time

However, it currently does not have any fields related to the ServiceWorker Static Routing API. Developers would benefit from having fields that provide information such as:

- the matched route (the route that the Static Routing API evaluated)
- the actual source from which the resource was retrieved
- the time it took to match the route
- the time to look up the cache for the cache source

This information will allow developers to measure the latency incurred by the API such as router evaluation time or time required to conduct cache lookup, or determine if the matched source is the final source used (can find out if the matched source failed to get the resource or not, and which source was used as the alternative).

title: New `trusted-types-eval` keyword for CSP script-src
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Content Security Policy (and Trusted Types)
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-csp/pull/665/commits/844456655493197e60e7657cc11f8dfcb505372f
* Explainer URL (if available):
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @lukewarlow
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @mozfreddyb @dveditz
* WebKit standards-position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/355

### Other information

This proposes a new `trusted-types-eval` keyword for the CSP script-src directive. The main use case for this new keyword is to allow enabling eval only in browsers that support and have Trusted Types enforced. Currently trusted types is used alongside `unsafe-eval` (if you need eval), which means that in browsers with no trusted types support eval is still allowed (completely unmitigated by the protections TT offer). This new keyword would prevent that situation.

title: Map mozilla positions to web-features IDs
body:
The [web-features repository](https://github.com/web-platform-dx/web-features) maintains a growing list of web platform features. This list acts as a hub for various web data such as browser-compat-data, Can I Use, specs, WPT, Chrome's usage counters, etc.

The most useful thing the web-features repo offers right now is a summary of browser support and a Baseline status per feature. The Baseline status, in particular, is used on the MDN Web Docs and Can I Use websites.
Other websites such as webstatus.dev use a bunch of information from web-features.

The [W3C WebDX CG](https://www.w3.org/community/webdx/) (which currently maintains the repo) [recently discussed](https://github.com/web-platform-dx/web-features/issues/186) mapping web-features entries to browser standard positions too.

This PR is a proposal for the first step towards achieving this. It adds IDs of features in the web-features repo to individual entries here. This is done by adding an optional `webFeaturesID` property to entries in `activities.json`. This property is a string which value matches filenames in https://github.com/web-platform-dx/web-features/tree/main/features (without the file extension).

If you agree with this approach, this will help us link Mozilla positions with a lot of other data about web platform features around various web properties.

I plan on proposing a similar PR for https://webkit.org/standards-positions/

cc @jgraham who we discussed this with.

### Other information

This API is a new loading strategy for ServiceWorker. ServiceWorkerAutoPreload is a mode where the browser issues a network request (i.e. a regular request which may result in a HTTP cache hit or an actual fetch) in parallel with the ServiceWorker bootstrap, and consumes the network request result inside the fetch handler.

The status in chromium can be tracked from https://chromestatus.com/feature/5194817700364288

This is an early-stage idea but we'd love early engagement from other implementers.

title: Backdrop filter mirror edgeMode
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Filter Effects
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://drafts.fxtf.org/filter-effects-2/#backdrop-filter-operation
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/w3c/fxtf-drafts/issues/374
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @flackr
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): N/A (this is a change to the way backdrop-filter renders)
* Bugzilla URL (optional):
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional):
* WebKit standards-position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/372

### Other information

This is specifically about the switch from the duplicate edgeMode to the mirror edgeMode for backdrop-filter sampling beyond the backdrop edges. The duplicate edgeMode leads to significant flickering in common scenarios and significantly overweights pixels at the edge into the blur, whereas mirroring back into the backdrop allows the smooth introduction of new content into the backdrop while still avoiding sampling outside of it (the motivation for using duplicate originally).

title: [css-sizing-4] `stretch` keyword for sizing properties
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: CSS Box Sizing Module Level 4 (specifically the section on `stretch`)
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://drafts.csswg.org/css-sizing-4/#valdef-width-stretch
* Explainer URL (if available): N/A
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @tabatkins, @fantasai, @jensimmons
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): https://caniuse.com/mdn-css_properties_width_stretch
* Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1789477
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): myself, @emilio
* WebKit standards-position: None filed yet that I could find.

### Other information
The `stretch` keyword is a standardized version of the behavior that's traditionally been exposed by the prefixed `-moz-available` and `-webkit-fill-available` CSS keywords. (Minor caveat: `-moz-available` only works in the inline axis for now, but `stretch` and `-webkit-fill-available` work in both axes.)  We've observed that [there are webcompat requirements for us to implement `-webkit-fill-available`](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1886561), and it seems the best way forward is to implement the standardized `stretch` behavior and use `-webkit-fill-available` as an alias for it (while recommending that sites use the standard keyword from here on out).

(@bfgeek noted in https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop-2022-viewport/issues/18#issuecomment-1268722823 that Chromium at least has been moving towards making `-webkit-fill-available` the same as the standardized `stretch` behavior.)

title: Selection API: getComposedRanges
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: getComposedRanges()
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/selection-api/#dom-selection-getcomposedranges
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/mfreed7/shadow-dom-selection
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @dizhang168 @mfreed7 @siliu1
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @sefeng211 @emilio
* WebKit standards-position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/376

### Other information

Current [getComposedRanges]( https://w3c.github.io/selection-api/#dom-selection-getcomposedranges) API has single shadowRoots parameter which is a rest parameter. We propose changing it to a dictionary that contains an array of shadow roots to be consistent with other shadow DOM API:
- [getHTML()](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#gethtmloptions)
- [caretPositionFromPoint()](https://drafts.csswg.org/cssom-view/#dictdef-caretpositionfrompointoptions)

We would also like to add `selectionRoot`. This argument "scopes" the selection, so that the returned selection endpoints are always descendants of element.

Proposed change:
```
sequence<StaticRange> getComposedRanges(optional GetComposedRangesOptions options = {});

dictionary GetComposedRangesOptions {
  sequence<ShadowRoot> shadowRoots = [];
  ShadowRoot selectionRoot;
};
```

Further, we need to re-evaluate API changes for the Range and StaticRange interface, to support nodes in different tree. Either we need to update existing definitions or we might need to add new interfaces. Help us resolve these discussions.

See:
Changes to Range, StaticRange: https://github.com/w3c/selection-api/issues/169
Change getComposedRanges’ parameter to a dictionary: https://github.com/w3c/selection-api/issues/176
Change getComposedRanges to have selectionRoot parameter: https://github.com/w3c/selection-api/issues/180
Main: https://github.com/w3c/selection-api/issues/161

title: CSS reading-flow
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: CSS reading-flow
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://drafts.csswg.org/css-display-4/#reading-flow
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/dizhang168/reading-order-items
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @dizhang168, @mfreed7, @rachelandrew
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @emilio
* WebKit standards-position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/378


### Other information

The CSS Working Group has resolved to add the new reading-flow property (https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/8589, [spec](https://drafts.csswg.org/css-display-4/#reading-flow)) to enable focus navigation in visual order for layout items that might not be displayed in source order (such as grid, flex and masonry items). Chromium is implementing the new property and opened a https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10407 on the needed HTML spec change.

We would like to seek Mozilla's position on implementing the CSS property.

Further, we would like to get feedback on the suggested [HTML proposal](https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10407) and the open questions on `display: contents` (https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/9230, https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10533).

title: Dynamic import maps
body:
<!-- Please use only the specification title as the issue title. -->

## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Dynamic import maps
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/10528
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/10528#issue-2437162429
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @yoavweiss
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @smaug---- @zcorpan
* WebKit standards-position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/381

### Other information
Import maps currently have to load before any ES module and there can only be a single import map per document. That makes them fragile and potentially slow to use in real-life scenarios: Any module that loads before them breaks the entire app, and in apps with many modules the become a large blocking resource, as the entire map for all possible modules needs to load first.

This proposal is to enable multiple import maps per document, by merging them in a consistent and deterministic way.

title: Future browsing context group dependency hint
body:
## Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

* Specification title: Future browsing context group dependency hint
* Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/future-browsing-context-group-dependency-hint
* Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/future-browsing-context-group-dependency-hint
* Proposal author(s) (`@`-mention GitHub accounts): @kjmcnee
* Caniuse.com URL (optional): 
* Bugzilla URL (optional): 
* Mozillians who can provide input (optional):
* WebKit standards-position: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/383

### Other information

This proposal extends the use of the "opener" rel type to same-window navigations to signal to the browser that the destination page will open a new window and the referring page expects to be able to access it. Some user agents perform browsing context group changes on navigation that aren't strictly necessary for security in order to improve performance. This results in named window reuse not being possible across a back navigation. Annotating an anchor element with "opener" will signal to the user agent that performing a browsing context group change would break a future opener relationship.

Regarding specification, this proposal would consist of a patch for the html spec. See here for details: https://github.com/explainers-by-googlers/future-browsing-context-group-dependency-hint?tab=readme-ov-file#specification-changes

Thanks.
